page.title: 11House Building at Deepcut
page.content: Bricks are used for the outside walls and turbo blocks for the inside. Turbo blocks are very light and look like grey Aero chocolate. The little pockets of air make them good for insulation. The bricklayer's mate carries the bricks in a hod. Downstairs inside walls are built of turbo blocks. Upstairs walls are built of wooden uprights and spaces between are covered with plaster board. The roof is built of triangular wooden frames held together with beams. Roofing felt is laid then battens. Tiles are then laid on those battens. The plaster board is fixed to walls with blobs of plaster, leaving a narrow gap. This, with roof insulation and double glazed windows, aids in keeping the house insulated.
